head.title: Oil-Import Fee Is a Cure Worse Than the Malady

hedline.hl1: Oil-Import Fee Is a Cure Worse Than the Malady

block.p: Your report on rising oil imports (Business Day, Nov. 19) did not say that some of the cures that were suggested might be worse than the problem itself.

Proponents of an oil-import fee, for example, fail to point out that such a policy would increase inflation and unemployment. Replacing high cost United States production with lower-cost oil from Canada, Mexico, Britain, Venezuela and other foreign producers has provided a needed boost to our economy. To correct the trade imbalance, we need to expand exports to foreign markets, not impose policies to raise export prices.

The effort to conserve oil and other nonrenewable energy resources must again become a national priority. Unfortunately, the Reagan Administration, with its free-market obsession, has eliminated or sharply reduced most programs for energy conservation and solar energy that helped reduce our energy gluttony.

What we need is a comprehensive energy program that promotes conservation and a shift to nonpolluting renewable energy sources, but does not create widespread economic dislocation. EDWIN S. ROTHSCHILD Assistant Director Citizen/Labor Energy Coalition Washington, Nov. 19, 1987
